title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: A vivid momentary image of some stranger, or, rather, of a formidable  glowing chintz gown belonging to some stranger, who might have been she, still rises perfectly certain to me, from my second or third year; but more probably it was her sister, my grand-aunt Barbara, of Annan, with whom I afterwards boarded when at school there (1806-1808), and whom I almost daily heard muttering and weeping about her ' dear Margaret,' and their parting ' at the dyke-end ' (near Cargenbridge, Dumfries neighbourhood, I suppose, perhaps six years before), ' sae little thinking it was for the last time ! ' It is inconceivable (till you have seen the documents) what the pecuniary poverty of Scotland was a hundred years ago; and, again (of which also i, for one, still more indubitably ' have the documents '), its spiritual opulence— opulence fast ending in these years, think some?
